project.teaser: The EU requires rapid and effective actions based on innovative detection concepts targeting quarantine, priority and other serious pests. Fair, healthy and environment-friendly food systems are threatened by increasing pest invasions due to climate change and a growing demand...
project.objective: The EU requires rapid and effective actions based on innovative detection concepts targeting quarantine, priority and other serious pests. Fair, healthy and environment-friendly food systems are threatened by increasing pest invasions due to climate change and a growing demand for high quality, pest-free food. The goal of PurPest is to develop, validate and demonstrate an innovative sensor platform that can rapidly detect five different pests during import and in the field to stop their establishment and reduce pesticide inputs by at least 50%. The sensor concept is based on detection of pest-specific volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by host plants invaded by one or several pests. PurPest will determine the VOC signature of Phytophthora ramorum, the Fall armyworm, the Cotton bollworm, the Brown marmorated stinkbug and the Pinewood nematode under different abiotic stress conditions. The VOC database will be exploited to optimize existing and develop new sensor concepts to detect pest-specific VOCs, starting from proof of concept (TRL3) to demonstration in field trials (TRL6). Non-invasive, reliable and rapid pest sensing platforms will increase pest screening efficiency from currently 3% to 80% of plant imports. Preventing outbreaks of new pests and site-specific pesticide use by early detection are the cornerstones of sustainable and integrated pest management (IPM). PurPest will evaluate the socio-economic and ecological impact of 5 pests and how the new detection concept affects these impacts. Direct communication with stakeholders via the advisory board, workshops and webinars is part of PurPest’s multi-actor approach to affirm involvement of all interest groups along the value chain The PurPest project is a strong multidisciplinary consortium with expertise from 10 countries, 7 universities, 5 research institutes, 4 SMEs and 2 governmental agencies.
project.title: Plant pest prevention through technology-guided monitoring and site-specific control
project.keywords: Sensors, pest detection, monitoring, volatile organic compounds, odours, import control

article.title: Sensing volatiles to monitor and manage invasive pests in agriculture and forestry

result.title: Advances in Eelctronic Nose Sensors for Plant Disease and Pest Detection

details.authors: Ana Fundurulic, Jorge M.S. Faria, Maria L. Inacio

result.title: First sensor system prototype
result.description: This demonstrator will be the first fully funcitonal SSP containitng the sensors that passed MS2 sensor selection.

result.title: List of VOCs and VOC patterns of target pests in pure culture
result.description: This deliverable will rely on collected VOCs, using the head space collectors from D1.1 that have been analysed in T1.5.

result.title: Practice Abstracts- batch 1
result.description: This deliverable contains at least 5 practice abstracts

result.title: List of VOCs released from relevant pest described in the literature
result.description: This deliverable will list VOCs that are good candidates for monitoring. The list will enable early testing of sensors for relevant VOCs before the controlled experiments are completed.

result.title: Project Website
result.description: Project website will include introduction to the project aim and objectives, the project partners and continuous updates on project news and publications.

result.title: Detailed Plan for dissemination and exploitation including communication activities
result.description: Chronological plan detailing the activities for dissemination of the project (e.g., journal publications, technical bulletins, congress participations, flash presentations, etc.)

result.title: Seven Portable head space VOC collection devices
result.description: The seven portable head space collectors will be make by JKI and sent to the different partners for collecting VOCs in the controlled experiments.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - PURPEST (Plant pest prevention through technology-guided monitoring and site-specific control)
result.teaser: One of the ambitious goals of the EU's Farm2Fork strategy is to reduce the use of pesticides by 50%. The expected increase in plant pests due to climate change, international trade and the intensification of food production systems offsets this target. PurPest aims to control...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

webItem.alternativeText: Demonstration of the Head space collection device (HSCD) to capture VOCs at the workshop at the JKI
Collection of VOCs from fruit trees in the field using the HSCD at JKI

result.title: Report on performance of individual sensor system components
result.description: During WP2 all the sensor componsnet will be tested in increasingly complex VOC mixtures. This report will summarise all the results and lay ground for the selection of sensor components for the SSP

result.title: First Compatible Sensor System Components to be integrated in WP3
result.description: This prototype will include those sensors that have shown to function in D2.2 and will be used in WP3 for advanced testing prior to sensor selection.

result.title: Literature review
result.description: Literature review on the potential impacts for the PurPest technology

result.title: First DMP draft
result.description: Data management plan. Important for establishing how data in the project is managed.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
